post.summary: Simulate an ACH Transfer to your account
post.description: Simulates an inbound ACH transfer to your account. This imitates initiating a transaction to an Increase account from a different financial institution. The transfer may be either a credit or a debit depending on if the `amount` is positive or negative. The result of calling this API will be either a [Transaction](#transactions) or a [Declined Transaction](#declined-transactions) depending on whether or not the transfer is allowed.

Simulates the submission of an [ACH Transfer](#ach-transfers) to the Federal Reserve. This transfer must first have a `status` of `pending_approval` or `pending_submission`. In production, Increase submits ACH Transfers to the Federal Reserve three times per day on weekdays. Since sandbox ACH Transfers are not submitted to the Federal Reserve, this endpoint allows you to skip that delay and transition the ACH Transfer to a status of `submitted`.

schema.description: The identifier of the ACH Transfer you wish to submit.

post.description: Simulates the return of an [ACH Transfer](#ach-transfers) by the Federal Reserve due to an error condition. This will also create a Transaction to account for the returned funds. This transfer must first have a `status` of `submitted`.

schema.description: The identifier of the ACH Transfer you wish to return.

post.description: If your account is configured to require approval for each transfer, this endpoint simulates the approval of an [Account Transfer](#account-transfers). You can also approve sandbox Account Transfers in the dashboard. This transfer must first have a `status` of `pending_approval`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Account Transfer you wish to complete.

post.description: Simulates the mailing of a [Check Transfer](#check-transfers), which happens once per weekday in production but can be sped up in sandbox. This transfer must first have a `status` of `pending_approval` or `pending_submission`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Check Transfer you wish to mail.

post.description: Simulates a [Check Transfer](#check-transfers) being deposited at a bank. This transfer must first have a `status` of `mailed`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Check Transfer you wish to mark deposited.

post.description: Simulates a [Check Transfer](#check-transfers) being returned via USPS to Increase. This transfer must first have a `status` of `mailed`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Check Transfer you wish to mark returned.

post.description: Simulates the submission of a [Check Deposit](#check-deposits) to the Federal Reserve. This Check Deposit must first have a `status` of `pending`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Check Deposit you wish to submit.

post.description: Simulates the rejection of a [Check Deposit](#check-deposits) by Increase due to factors like poor image quality. This Check Deposit must first have a `status` of `pending`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Check Deposit you wish to reject.

post.description: Simulates the return of a [Check Deposit](#check-deposits). This Check Deposit must first have a `status` of `submitted`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Check Deposit you wish to return.

post.summary: Simulate a Wire Transfer to your account
post.description: Simulates an inbound Wire Transfer to your account.
Simulates the submission of a [Wire Transfer](#wire-transfers) to the Federal Reserve. This transfer must first have a `status` of `pending_approval` or `pending_creating`.

schema.description: The identifier of the Wire Transfer you wish to submit.

post.description: Simulates the reversal of a [Wire Transfer](#wire-transfers) by the Federal Reserve due to error conditions. This will also create a [Transaction](#transaction) to account for the returned funds. This Wire Transfer must first have a `status` of `complete`.'

schema.description: The identifier of the Wire Transfer you wish to reverse.

post.summary: Simulate an Inbound Wire Drawdown request being created
post.description: Simulates the receival of an [Inbound Wire Drawdown Request](#inbound-wire-drawdown-requests).

post.summary: Simulate an authorization on a Card
post.description: Simulates a purchase authorization on a [Card](#cards). Depending on the balance available to the card and the `amount` submitted, the authorization activity will result in a [Pending Transaction](#pending-transactions) of type `card_authorization` or a [Declined Transaction](#declined-transactions) of type `card_decline`. You can pass either a Card id or a [Digital Wallet Token](#digital-wallet-tokens) id to simulate the two different ways purchases can be made.

Simulates the settlement of an authorization by a card acquirer. After a card authorization is created, the merchant will eventually send a settlement. This simulates that event, which may occur many days after the purchase in production. The amount settled can be different from the amount originally authorized, for example, when adding a tip to a restaurant bill.

post.summary: Simulate a refund on a card
post.description: Simulates refunding a card transaction. The full value of the original sandbox transaction is refunded.

post.summary: Simulates advancing the state of a card dispute
post.description: After a [Card Dispute](#card-disputes) is created in production, the dispute will be reviewed. Since no review happens in sandbox, this endpoint simulates moving a Card Dispute into a rejected or accepted state. A Card Dispute can only be actioned one time and must have a status of `pending_reviewing`.

schema.description: The dispute you would like to action.

post.summary: Simulate digital wallet provisioning for a card
post.description: Simulates a user attempting add a [Card](#cards) to a digital wallet such as Apple Pay.

200.description: Inbound Digital Wallet Token Request Simulation Result

post.summary: Simulate a Real Time Payments Transfer to your account
post.description: Simulates an inbound Real Time Payments transfer to your account. Real Time Payments are a beta feature.

200.description: Inbound Real Time Payments Transfer Simulation Result

post.summary: Simulate an Account Statement being created
post.description: Simulates an [Account Statement](#account-statements) being created for an account. In production, Account Statements are generated once per month.

post.summary: Simulate a tax document being created
post.description: Simulates an tax document being created for an account.

tags.name: Accounts
tags.description: Accounts are your bank accounts with Increase. They store money, receive transfers, and send payments. They earn interest and have depository insurance.

tags.name: Account Numbers
tags.description: Each account can have multiple account and routing numbers. We recommend that you use a set per vendor. This is similar to how you use different passwords for different websites. Account numbers can also be used to seamlessly reconcile inbound payments. Generating a unique account number per vendor ensures you always know the originator of an incoming payment.

tags.name: Cards
tags.description: Cards are commercial credit cards. They'll immediately work for online purchases after you create them. All cards maintain a credit limit of 100% of the Accounts available balance at the time of transaction. Funds are deducted from the Account upon transaction settlement.

tags.name: Card Disputes
tags.description: If unauthorized activity occurs on a card, you can create a Card Dispute and we'll return the funds if appropriate.

tags.name: Card Profiles
tags.description: This contains artwork and metadata relating to a Card's appearance in digital wallet apps like Apple Pay and Google Pay. For more information, see our guide on [digital card artwork](https://increase.com/documentation/card-art)

tags.name: Digital Wallet Tokens
tags.description: A Digital Wallet Token is created when a user adds a Card to their Apple Pay or Google Pay app. The Digital Wallet Token can be used for purchases just like a Card.

tags.name: Transactions
tags.description: Transactions are the immutable additions and removals of money from your bank account. They're the equivalent of line items on your bank statement.

tags.name: Pending Transactions
tags.description: Pending Transactions are potential future additions and removals of money from your bank account.

tags.name: Declined Transactions
tags.description: Declined Transactions are refused additions and removals of money from your bank account. For example, Declined Transactions are caused when your Account has an insufficient balance or your Limits are triggered.

tags.name: Limits
tags.description: You can set limits at the Account, Account Number, or Card level. Limits applied to Accounts will apply to all Account Numbers and Cards in the Account. You can specify any number of Limits and they will all be applied to inbound debits and card authorizations. Volume and count Limits are designed to prevent unauthorized debits.

tags.name: Account Transfers
tags.description: Account transfers move funds between your own accounts at Increase.

tags.name: ACH Transfers
tags.description: ACH transfers move funds between your Increase account and any other account accessible by the Automated Clearing House (ACH).

tags.name: ACH Prenotifications
tags.description: ACH Prenotifications are one way you can verify account and routing numbers by Automated Clearing House (ACH).

tags.name: Inbound ACH Transfer Returns
tags.description: If unauthorized activity occurs via ACH, you can create an Inbound ACH Transfer Return and we'll reverse the transaction. You can create an Inbound ACH Transfer return the first two days after receiving an Inbound ACH Transfer.

tags.name: Wire Transfers
tags.description: Wire transfers move funds between your Increase account and any other account accessible by Fedwire.

tags.name: Wire Drawdown Requests
tags.description: Wire drawdown requests enable you to request that someone else send you a wire. This feature is in beta; reach out to [support@increase.com](mailto:support@increase.com) to learn more.

tags.name: Inbound Wire Drawdown Requests
tags.description: Inbound wire drawdown requests are requests from someone else to send them a wire. This feature is in beta; reach out to [support@increase.com](mailto:support@increase.com) to learn more.

tags.name: Check Transfers
tags.description: Check Transfers move funds from your Increase account by mailing a physical check.

tags.name: Check Deposits
tags.description: Check Deposits allow you to deposit images of paper checks into your account.

tags.name: Routing Numbers
tags.description: Routing numbers are used to identify your bank in a financial transaction.

tags.name: External Accounts
tags.description: External Accounts represent accounts at financial institutions other than Increase. You can use this API to store their details for reuse.

tags.name: Entities
tags.description: Entities are the legal entities that own accounts. They can be people, corporations, partnerships, or trusts.

tags.name: Account Statements
tags.description: Account Statements are generated monthly for every active Account. You can access the statement's data via the API or retrieve a PDF with its details via its associated File.

tags.name: Files
tags.description: Files are objects that represent a file hosted on Increase's servers. The file may have been uploaded by you (for example, when uploading a check image) or it may have been created by Increase (for example, an autogenerated statement PDF).

tags.name: Documents
tags.description: Increase generates certain documents / forms automatically for your application; they can be listed here. Currently the only supported document type is IRS Form 1099-INT.

tags.name: Events
tags.description: Events are records of things that happened to objects in the API. They also result in webhooks being generated.

tags.name: Event Subscriptions
tags.description: Webhooks are event notifications we send to you by HTTPS POST requests. Event Subscriptions are how you configure your application to listen for them. You can create an Event Subscription through your [developer dashboard](https://dashboard.increase.com/developers/webhooks) or the API. For more information, see our [webhooks guide](https://increase.com/documentation/webhooks).

tags.name: Real-Time Decisions
tags.description: Real Time Decisions are created when your application needs to take action in real-time to some event such as a card authorization. Real time decisions are currently in beta; please contact support@increase.com if you're interested in trying them out!

tags.name: Groups
tags.description: Groups represent organizations using Increase. You can retrieve information about your own organization via the API, or (more commonly) OAuth platforms can retrieve information about the organizations that have granted them access.

tags.name: OAuth Connections
tags.description: When a user authorizes your OAuth application, an OAuth Connection object is created.

tags.name: Simulations
tags.description: When building your application, you can use these APIs to simulate external effects. They can be helpful to quickly test events that might take several hours in the real world (like receiving a wire or ACH). *These APIs will only work in the sandbox.* If you have a sandbox [Event Subscription](#event-subscriptions) configured, calling these APIs will also result in the appropriate webhooks being sent to your endpoint.

amount.description: The transfer amount in cents. A positive amount originates a credit transfer pushing funds to the receiving account. A negative amount originates a debit transfer pulling funds from the receiving account.

company_descriptive_date.description: The description of the date of the transfer, usually in the format `YYYYMMDD`. This is included in the transfer data sent to the receiving bank.

company_discretionary_data.description: The data you choose to associate with the transfer. This is included in the transfer data sent to the receiving bank.

funding.description: The type of the account to which the transfer will be sent.

individual_id.description: Your identifer for the transfer recipient.

individual_name.description: The name of the transfer recipient. This value is informational and not verified by the recipient's bank.

require_approval.description: Whether the transfer requires explicit approval via the dashboard or API.

routing_number.description: The American Bankers' Association (ABA) Routing Transit Number (RTN) for the destination account.

standard_entry_class_code.description: The Standard Entry Class (SEC) code to use for the transfer.

statement_descriptor.description: A description you choose to give the transfer. This will be saved with the transfer details, displayed in the dashboard, and returned by the API. If `individual_name` and `company_name` are not explicitly set by this API, the `statement_descriptor` will be sent in those fields to the receiving bank to help the customer recognize the transfer. You are highly encouraged to pass `individual_name` and `company_name` instead of relying on this fallback.

x-enum-descriptions: The customer no longer authorizes this transaction. The Nacha return code is R07.
The customer asked for the payment to be stopped. This reason is only allowed for debits. The Nacha return code is R08.
The customer advises that the debit was unauthorized. The Nacha return code is R10.
The payee is deceased. The Nacha return code is R14.
The account holder is deceased. The Nacha return code is R15.
The customer refused a credit entry. This reason is only allowed for credits. The Nacha return code is R23.
The account holder identified this transaction as a duplicate. The Nacha return code is R24.
The corporate customer no longer authorizes this transaction. The Nacha return code is R29.

status.description: The status to update the Event Subscription with.
x-enum-descriptions: The subscription is active and Events will be delivered normally.
The subscription is temporarily disabled and Events will not be delivered.
The subscription is permanently disabled and Events will not be delivered.

card_authorization.description: If the Real-Time Decision relates to a card authorization attempt, this object contains your response to the authorization.

decision.description: Whether the card authorization should be approved or declined.

digital_wallet_token.description: If the Real-Time Decision relates to a digital wallet token provisioning attempt, this object contains your response to the attempt.

approval.description: If your application approves the provisioning attempt, this contains metadata about the digital wallet token that will be generated.

card_profile_id.description: The identifier of the Card Profile to assign to the Digital Wallet token.

phone.description: A phone number that can be used to verify the cardholder via one-time passcode over SMS.

email.description: An email address that can be used to verify the cardholder via one-time passcode.

decline.description: If your application declines the provisioning attempt, this contains details about the decline.

reason.description: Why the tokenization attempt was declined. This is for logging purposes only and is not displayed to the end-user.

digital_wallet_authentication.description: If the Real-Time Decision relates to a digital wallet authentication attempt, this object contains your response to the authentication.

result.description: Whether your application was able to deliver the one-time passcode.
x-enum-descriptions: Your application successfully delivered the one-time passcode to the cardholder.
Your application failed to deliver the one-time passcode to the cardholder.

account_number_id.description: The identifier of the Account Number the inbound ACH Transfer is for.

amount.description: The transfer amount in cents. A positive amount originates a credit transfer pushing funds to the receiving account. A negative amount originates a debit transfer pulling funds from the receiving account.

company_descriptive_date.description: The description of the date of the transfer.

company_discretionary_data.description: Data associated with the transfer set by the sender.

company_entry_description.description: The description of the transfer set by the sender.

reason.description: The reason why the Federal Reserve or destination bank returned this transfer. Defaults to `no_account`.
x-enum-descriptions: Insufficient funds in the source account.
The account does not exist or the receiving bank was unable to locate it.
The account number is invalid at the receiving bank.
The account was frozen per the Office of Foreign Assets Control.
The receiving bank account refused a credit transfer.
The receiving bank rejected because of an incorrect Standard Entry Class code.
The corporate customer reversed the transfer.
The receiving bank stopped payment on this transfer.
The receiving bank account does not perform transfers.
The receiving bank account does not have enough available balance for the transfer.
The amount field is incorrect or too large.
The customer who initiated the transfer revoked authorization.
The receiving bank is unable to process a field in the transfer.
The individual name field was invalid.
The originating financial institution reversed the transfer.
The addenda record is incorrect or missing.
The receiving bank's regulatory supervisor has limited their participation.
The outbound international ACH transfer was incorrect.

reason.description: The reason why the Check Transfer was returned to Increase.

The check arrived and the recipient refused to deposit it.

amount.description: The transfer amount in cents. Must be positive.

beneficiary_address_line2.description: Line 2 of the drawdown request's beneficiary's address.

debtor_account_number.description: The account number of the account that sent the transfer.

remittance_information.description: Additional information included with the transfer.

The identifier of the Account the tax document is for.

account.title: Account
account.description: Accounts are your bank accounts with Increase. They store money, receive transfers, and send payments. They earn interest and have depository insurance.

balances.title: Balances
balances.description: The Account's balances in the minor unit of its currency. For dollars, for example, these values will represent cents.

current_balance.description: The Account's current balance, representing the sum of all posted Transactions on the Account.

available_balance.description: The Account's available balance, representing the current balance less any open Pending Transactions on the Account.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time at which the Account was created.

currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the Account currency.

entity_id.description: The identifier for the Entity the Account belongs to.

informational_entity_id.description: The identifier of an Entity that, while not owning the Account, is associated with its activity.

interest_accrued.description: The interest accrued but not yet paid, expressed as a string containing a floating-point value.

interest_accrued_at.description: The latest [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date on which interest was accrued.

name.description: The name you choose for the Account.

status.description: The status of the Account.
x-enum-descriptions: Open Accounts that are ready to use.
Closed Accounts on which no new activity can occur.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `account`.

next_cursor.description: A pointer to a place in the list.

account_number.title: Account Number
account_number.description: Each account can have multiple account and routing numbers. We recommend that you use a set per vendor. This is similar to how you use different passwords for different websites. Account numbers can also be used to seamlessly reconcile inbound payments. Generating a unique account number per vendor ensures you always know the originator of an incoming payment.

account_id.description: The identifier for the account this Account Number belongs to.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time at which the Account Number was created.

name.description: The name you choose for the Account Number.

routing_number.description: The American Bankers' Association (ABA) Routing Transit Number (RTN).

status.description: This indicates if payments can be made to the Account Number.
x-enum-descriptions: The account number is temporarily disabled.
The account number is permanently disabled.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `account_number`.

account_number_list.title: Account Number List
account_number_list.description: A list of Account Number objects

next_cursor.description: A pointer to a place in the list.

card.title: Card
card.description: Cards are commercial credit cards. They'll immediately work for online purchases after you create them. All cards maintain a credit limit of 100% of the Accounts available balance at the time of transaction. Funds are deducted from the Account upon transaction settlement.

account_id.description: The identifier for the account this card belongs to.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which the Card was created.

description.description: The card's description for display purposes.

last4.description: The last 4 digits of the Card's Primary Account Number.

expiration_month.description: The month the card expires in M format (e.g., August is 8).

expiration_year.description: The year the card expires in YYYY format (e.g., 2025).

status.description: This indicates if payments can be made with the card.

line1.description: The first line of the billing address.

line2.description: The second line of the billing address.

city.description: The city of the billing address.

state.description: The US state of the billing address.

postal_code.description: The postal code of the billing address.

digital_wallet.title: Digital Wallet
digital_wallet.description: The contact information used in the two-factor steps for digital wallet card creation. At least one field must be present to complete the digital wallet steps.

email.description: An email address that can be used to verify the cardholder via one-time passcode over email.

phone.description: A phone number that can be used to verify the cardholder via one-time passcode over SMS.

card_profile_id.description: The card profile assigned to this digital card. Card profiles may also be assigned at the program level.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `card`.

card_details.title: Card Details
card_details.description: An object containing the sensitive details (card number, cvc, etc) for a Card.

card_id.description: The identifier for the Card for which sensitive details have been returned.

expiration_month.description: The month the card expires in M format (e.g., August is 8).

expiration_year.description: The year the card expires in YYYY format (e.g., 2025).

verification_code.description: The three-digit verification code for the card. It's also known as the Card Verification Code (CVC), the Card Verification Value (CVV), or the Card Identification (CID).

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `card_details`.

next_cursor.description: A pointer to a place in the list.

card_dispute.description: If unauthorized activity occurs on a card, you can create a Card Dispute and we'll return the funds if appropriate.

status.description: The results of the Dispute investigation.

acceptance.description: If the Card Dispute's status is `accepted`, this will contain details of the successful dispute.

card_dispute_list.description: A list of Card Dispute objects

card_profile.title: Card Profile
card_profile.description: This contains artwork and metadata relating to a Card's appearance in digital wallet apps like Apple Pay and Google Pay. For more information, see our guide on [digital card artwork](https://increase.com/documentation/card-art)

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which the Card Dispute was created.

status.description: The status of the Card Profile.

digital_wallets.title: Digital Wallets
digital_wallets.description: How Cards should appear in digital wallets such as Apple Pay. Different wallets will use these values to render card artwork appropriately for their app.

text_color.title: Text Color
text_color.description: The Card's text color, specified as an RGB triple.

red.description: The value of the red channel in the RGB color.

green.description: The value of the green channel in the RGB color.

blue.description: The value of the blue channel in the RGB color.

issuer_name.description: A user-facing description for whoever is issuing the card.

card_description.description: A user-facing description for the card itself.

contact_website.description: A website the user can visit to view and receive support for their card.

contact_email.description: An email address the user can contact to receive support for their card.

contact_phone.description: A phone number the user can contact to receive support for their card.

background_image_file_id.description: The identifier of the File containing the card's front image.

app_icon_file_id.description: The identifier of the File containing the card's icon image.

card_profile_list.description: A list of Card Profile objects

digital_wallet_token.title: Digital Wallet Token
digital_wallet_token.description: A Digital Wallet Token is created when a user adds a Card to their Apple Pay or Google Pay app. The Digital Wallet Token can be used for purchases just like a Card.

card_id.description: The identifier for the Card this Digital Wallet Token belongs to.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which the Card was created.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.description: Transactions are the immutable additions and removals of money from your bank account. They're the equivalent of line items on your bank statement.

account_id.description: The identifier for the Account the Transaction belongs to.

amount.description: The Transaction amount in the minor unit of its currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the Transaction's currency. This will match the currency on the Transcation's Account.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date on which the Transaction occured.

description.description: For a Transaction related to a transfer, this is the description you provide. For a Transaction related to a payment, this is the description the vendor provides.

route_id.description: The identifier for the route this Transaction came through. Routes are things like cards and ACH details.

route_type.description: The type of the route this Transaction came through.

source.title: Transaction Source
source.description: This is an object giving more details on the network-level event that caused the Transaction. Note that for backwards compatibility reasons, additional undocumented keys may appear in this object. These should be treated as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

amount.description: The pending amount in the minor unit of the transaction's currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

ach_check_conversion.description: A ACH Check Conversion object. This field will be present in the JSON response if and only if `category` is equal to `ach_check_conversion`.

ach_transfer_return.description: A ACH Transfer Return object. This field will be present in the JSON response if and only if `category` is equal to `ach_transfer_return`.

electronic_commerce_indicator.description: For electronic commerce transactions, this identifies the level of security used in obtaining the customer's payment credential. For mail or telephone order transactions, identifies the type of mail or telephone order.
x-enum-descriptions: Single transaction of a mail/phone order: Use to indicate that the transaction is a mail/phone order purchase, not a recurring transaction or installment payment. For domestic transactions in the US region, this value may also indicate one bill payment transaction in the card-present or card-absent environments.
Recurring transaction: Payment indicator used to indicate a recurring transaction that originates from an acquirer in the US region.

Installment payment: Payment indicator used to indicate one purchase of goods or services that is billed to the account in multiple charges over a period of time agreed upon by the cardholder and merchant from transactions that originate from an acquirer in the US region.
Unknown classification: other mail order: Use to indicate that the type of mail/telephone order is unknown.
Secure electronic commerce transaction: Use to indicate that the electronic commerce transaction has been authenticated using e.g., 3-D Secure

Non-authenticated security transaction at a 3-D Secure-capable merchant, and merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction where the merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure, but was unable to complete the authentication because the issuer or cardholder does not participate in the 3-D Secure program.

Non-authenticated security transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that uses data encryption for security however , cardholder authentication is not performed using 3-D Secure.
Non-secure transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that has no data protection.

point_of_service_entry_mode.description: The method used to enter the cardholder's primary account number and card expiration date

x-enum-descriptions: Single transaction of a mail/phone order: Use to indicate that the transaction is a mail/phone order purchase, not a recurring transaction or installment payment. For domestic transactions in the US region, this value may also indicate one bill payment transaction in the card-present or card-absent environments.
Recurring transaction: Payment indicator used to indicate a recurring transaction that originates from an acquirer in the US region.

Installment payment: Payment indicator used to indicate one purchase of goods or services that is billed to the account in multiple charges over a period of time agreed upon by the cardholder and merchant from transactions that originate from an acquirer in the US region.
Unknown classification: other mail order: Use to indicate that the type of mail/telephone order is unknown.
Secure electronic commerce transaction: Use to indicate that the electronic commerce transaction has been authenticated using e.g., 3-D Secure

Non-authenticated security transaction at a 3-D Secure-capable merchant, and merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction where the merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure, but was unable to complete the authentication because the issuer or cardholder does not participate in the 3-D Secure program.

Non-authenticated security transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that uses data encryption for security however , cardholder authentication is not performed using 3-D Secure.
Non-secure transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that has no data protection.

point_of_service_entry_mode.description: The method used to enter the cardholder's primary account number and card expiration date
x-enum-descriptions: Magnetic stripe read, without card verification value
Transaction iniated using a credential that has previously been stored on file

Contact chip card, without card verification value

limit.title: Limit
limit.description: You can set limits at the Account, Account Number, or Card level. Limits applied to Accounts will apply to all Account Numbers and Cards in the Account. You can specify any number of Limits and they will all be applied to inbound debits and card authorizations. Volume and count Limits are designed to prevent unauthorized debits.

interval.description: The interval for the metric. This is required if `metric` is `count` or `volume`.
x-enum-descriptions: Enforce the Limit based on the trailing 24 hour period.
Enforce the Limit based on the trailing seven days.
Enforce the Limit based on the trailing month, going back to the current day in the previous month, or as close as possible given month length differences.
Enforce the Limit based on the trailing 365 days.
Enforce the Limit for all time.
The maximum number of debits allowed.
The maximum volume of debits allowed in the minor unit of the model's currency.

model_id.description: The identifier of the Account Number, Account, or Card the Limit applies to.

model_type.description: The type of the model you wish to associate the Limit with.
x-enum-descriptions: Enforce the Limit for the entire account.
Enforce the Limit for this specific route.
Enforce the Limit for this specific card.

status.description: The current status of the Limit.

amount.description: The rejected amount in the minor unit of check's currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the check's currency.

reason.description: Why the check deposit was rejected.
x-enum-descriptions: This is a duplicate check submission.
This check has poor image quality.
The check was deposited with the incorrect amount.
The check is made out to someone other than the account holder.
This check was not eligible for mobile deposit.
The check was rejected for an unknown reason.

rejected_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which the check deposit was rejected.

deposit_return.title: Check Deposit Return
deposit_return.description: If your deposit is returned, this will contain details as to why it was returned.

amount.description: The amount in the minor unit of the transaction's currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

returned_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which the check deposit was returned.

currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the transaction's currency.

check_deposit_id.description: The identifier of the Check Deposit that was returned.

transaction_id.description: The identifier of the transaction that reversed the original check deposit transaction.

x-enum-descriptions: The check doesn't allow ACH conversion.
The check has already been deposited.
No account was found matching the check details.
The payment has been stopped by the account holder.
The reason for the return is unknown.
The image doesn't match the details submitted.
The image could not be read.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `check_deposit`.

check_deposit_list.description: A list of Check Deposit objects

external_account.title: External Account
external_account.description: External Accounts represent accounts at financial institutions other than Increase. You can use this API to store their details for reuse.

description.description: The External Account's description for display purposes.

status.description: The External Account's status.
x-enum-descriptions: The External Account is archived and won't appear in the dashboard.

routing_number.description: The American Bankers' Association (ABA) Routing Transit Number (RTN).

funding.description: The type of the account to which the transfer will be sent.

verification_status.description: If you have verified ownership of the External Account.

The External Account is in the process of being verified.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `external_account`.

entity.title: Entity
entity.description: Entities are the legal entities that own accounts. They can be people, corporations, partnerships, or trusts.

incorporation_state.description: The two-letter United States Postal Service (USPS) abbreviation for the corporation's state of incorporation.

account_statement_list.description: A list of Account Statement objects

next_cursor.description: A pointer to a place in the list.

account_statement.title: Account Statement
account_statement.description: Account Statements are generated monthly for every active Account. You can access the statement's data via the API or retrieve a PDF with its details via its associated File.

account_id.description: The identifier for the Account this Account Statement belongs to.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time at which the Account Statement was created.

file_id.description: The identifier of the File containing a PDF of the statement.

statement_period_start.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time representing the start of the period the Account Statement covers.

statement_period_end.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time representing the end of the period the Account Statement covers.

starting_balance.description: The Account's balance at the start of its statement period.

ending_balance.description: The Account's balance at the start of its statement period.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `account_statement`.

file.title: File
file.description: Files are objects that represent a file hosted on Increase's servers. The file may have been uploaded by you (for example, when uploading a check image) or it may have been created by Increase (for example, an autogenerated statement PDF).

created_at.description: The time the File was created.

purpose.description: What the File will be used for. We may add additional possible values for this enum over time; your application should be able to handle such additions gracefully.
x-enum-descriptions: An image of the front of a check, used for check deposits.
An image of the back of a check, used for check deposits.
An image of a government-issued ID.
A file purpose not covered by any of the other cases.
A legal document forming a trust.
A card image to be rendered inside digital wallet apps. This must be a 1536x969 pixel PNG.
An icon for you app to be rendered inside digital wallet apps. This must be a 100x100 pixel PNG.
A supplemental document associated an an Entity.

description.description: A description of the File.

direction.description: Whether the File was generated by Increase or by you and sent to Increase.
x-enum-descriptions: This File was sent by you to Increase.
This File was generated by Increase.

filename.description: The filename that was provided upon upload or generated by Increase.

download_url.description: A URL from where the File can be downloaded at this point in time. The location of this URL may change over time.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `file`.

next_cursor.description: A pointer to a place in the list.
A pointer to a place in the list.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `document`.

event_subscription.title: Event Subscription
event_subscription.description: Webhooks are event notifications we send to you by HTTPS POST requests. Event Subscriptions are how you configure your application to listen for them. You can create an Event Subscription through your [developer dashboard](https://dashboard.increase.com/developers/webhooks) or the API. For more information, see our [webhooks guide](https://increase.com/documentation/webhooks).

real_time_decision.title: Real-Time Decision
real_time_decision.description: Real Time Decisions are created when your application needs to take action in real-time to some event such as a card authorization. Real time decisions are currently in beta; please contact support@increase.com if you're interested in trying them out!

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which the Real-Time Decision was created.

timeout_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date and time at which your application can no longer respond to the Real-Time Decision.

status.description: The status of the Real-Time Decision.
x-enum-descriptions: The decision is pending action via real-time webhook.
Your webhook actioned the real-time decision.
Your webhook failed to respond to the authorization in time.

category.description: The category of the Real-Time Decision.
x-enum-descriptions: A card is being loaded into a digital wallet.
A card is being loaded into a digital wallet and requires cardholder authentication.

card_authorization.title: Card Authorization
card_authorization.description: Fields related to a card authorization.

merchant_acceptor_id.description: The merchant identifier (commonly abbreviated as MID) of the merchant the card is transacting with.

merchant_descriptor.description: The merchant descriptor of the merchant the card is transacting with.

merchant_category_code.description: The Merchant Category Code (commonly abbreviated as MCC) of the merchant the card is transacting with.

merchant_city.description: The city the merchant resides in.

merchant_country.description: The country the merchant resides in.

network.description: The payment network used to process this card authorization

electronic_commerce_indicator.description: For electronic commerce transactions, this identifies the level of security used in obtaining the customer's payment credential. For mail or telephone order transactions, identifies the type of mail or telephone order.
x-enum-descriptions: Single transaction of a mail/phone order: Use to indicate that the transaction is a mail/phone order purchase, not a recurring transaction or installment payment. For domestic transactions in the US region, this value may also indicate one bill payment transaction in the card-present or card-absent environments.
Recurring transaction: Payment indicator used to indicate a recurring transaction that originates from an acquirer in the US region.

Installment payment: Payment indicator used to indicate one purchase of goods or services that is billed to the account in multiple charges over a period of time agreed upon by the cardholder and merchant from transactions that originate from an acquirer in the US region.
Unknown classification: other mail order: Use to indicate that the type of mail/telephone order is unknown.
Secure electronic commerce transaction: Use to indicate that the electronic commerce transaction has been authenticated using e.g., 3-D Secure

Non-authenticated security transaction at a 3-D Secure-capable merchant, and merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction where the merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure, but was unable to complete the authentication because the issuer or cardholder does not participate in the 3-D Secure program.

Non-authenticated security transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that uses data encryption for security however , cardholder authentication is not performed using 3-D Secure.
Non-secure transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that has no data protection.

point_of_service_entry_mode.description: The method used to enter the cardholder's primary account number and card expiration date
x-enum-descriptions: Magnetic stripe read, without card verification value
Transaction iniated using a credential that has previously been stored on file
Contactless read of magnetic stripe data
Contact chip card, without card verification value

decision.description: Whether or not the authorization was approved.

card_id.description: The identifier of the Card that is being authorized.

account_id.description: The identifier of the Account the authorization will debit.

presentment_amount.description: The amount of the attempted authorization in the currency the card user sees at the time of purchase, in the minor unit of that currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

presentment_currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the currency the user sees at the time of purchase.

settlement_amount.description: The amount of the attempted authorization in the currency it will be settled in. This currency is the same as that of the Account the card belongs to.

settlement_currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the currency the transaction will be settled in.

digital_wallet_token.title: Digital Wallet Token
digital_wallet_token.description: Fields related to a digital wallet token provisioning attempt.

decision.description: Whether or not the provisioning request was approved. This will be null until the real time decision is responded to.

card_id.description: The identifier of the Card that is being tokenized.

digital_wallet.description: The digital wallet app being used.

card_profile_id.description: The identifier of the Card Profile that was set via the real time decision. This will be null until the real time decision is responded to or if the real time decision did not set a card profile.

digital_wallet_authentication.title: Digital Wallet Authentication
digital_wallet_authentication.description: Fields related to a digital wallet authentication attempt.

result.description: Whether your application successfully delivered the one-time passcode.
x-enum-descriptions: Your application successfully delivered the one-time passcode to the cardholder.
Your application failed to deliver the one-time passcode to the cardholder.

card_id.description: The identifier of the Card that is being tokenized.

digital_wallet.description: The digital wallet app being used.

channel.description: The channel to send the card user their one-time passcode.

one_time_passcode.description: The one-time passcode to send the card user.

phone.description: The phone number to send the one-time passcode to if `channel` is equal to `sms`.

email.description: The email to send the one-time passcode to if `channel` is equal to `email`.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `real_time_decision`.

group.title: Group
group.description: Groups represent organizations using Increase. You can retrieve information about your own organization via the API, or (more commonly) OAuth platforms can retrieve information about the organizations that have granted them access.

activation_status.description: If the Group is activated or not.

ach_debit_status.description: If the Group is allowed to create ACH debits.
x-enum-descriptions: The Group cannot make ACH debits.
The Group can make ACH debits.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time at which the Group was created.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `group`.

oauth_connection_list.title: OAuth Connection List
oauth_connection_list.description: A list of OAuth Connection objects

next_cursor.description: A pointer to a place in the list.

oauth_connection.title: OAuth Connection
oauth_connection.description: When a user authorizes your OAuth application, an OAuth Connection object is created.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) timestamp when the OAuth Connection was created.

group_id.description: The identifier of the Group that has authorized your OAuth application.

status.description: Whether the connection is active.
x-enum-descriptions: The OAuth connection is permanently deactivated.

type.description: A constant representing the object's type. For this resource it will always be `oauth_connection`.

inbound_ach_transfer_simulation_result.title: Inbound ACH Transfer Simulation Result
inbound_ach_transfer_simulation_result.description: The results of an inbound ACH Transfer simulation.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.description: If the ACH Transfer attempt succeeds, this will contain the resulting [Transaction](#transactions) object. The Transaction's `source` will be of `category: inbound_ach_transfer`.

account_id.description: The identifier for the Account the Transaction belongs to.

amount.description: The Transaction amount in the minor unit of its currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the Transaction's currency. This will match the currency on the Transcation's Account.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date on which the Transaction occured.

description.description: For a Transaction related to a transfer, this is the description you provide. For a Transaction related to a payment, this is the description the vendor provides.

route_id.description: The identifier for the route this Transaction came through. Routes are things like cards and ACH details.

route_type.description: The type of the route this Transaction came through.

source.title: Transaction Source
source.description: This is an object giving more details on the network-level event that caused the Transaction. Note that for backwards compatibility reasons, additional undocumented keys may appear in this object. These should be treated as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

category.description: The type of transaction that took place. We may add additional possible values for this enum over time; your application should be able to handle such additions gracefully.
x-enum-descriptions: The Transaction was created by a Account Transfer Intention object. Details will be under the `account_transfer_intention` object.
The Transaction was created by a ACH Check Conversion Return object. Details will be under the `ach_check_conversion_return` object.
The Transaction was created by a ACH Check Conversion object. Details will be under the `ach_check_conversion` object.
The Transaction was created by a ACH Transfer Intention object. Details will be under the `ach_transfer_intention` object.
The Transaction was created by a ACH Transfer Rejection object. Details will be under the `ach_transfer_rejection` object.
The Transaction was created by a ACH Transfer Return object. Details will be under the `ach_transfer_return` object.
The Transaction was created by a Card Dispute Acceptance object. Details will be under the `card_dispute_acceptance` object.
The Transaction was created by a Card Refund object. Details will be under the `card_refund` object.
The Transaction was created by a Card Settlement object. Details will be under the `card_settlement` object.
The Transaction was created by a Check Deposit Acceptance object. Details will be under the `check_deposit_acceptance` object.
The Transaction was created by a Check Deposit Return object. Details will be under the `check_deposit_return` object.
The Transaction was created by a Check Transfer Intention object. Details will be under the `check_transfer_intention` object.
The Transaction was created by a Check Transfer Return object. Details will be under the `check_transfer_return` object.
The Transaction was created by a Check Transfer Rejection object. Details will be under the `check_transfer_rejection` object.
The Transaction was created by a Check Transfer Stop Payment Request object. Details will be under the `check_transfer_stop_payment_request` object.
The Transaction was created by a Dispute Resolution object. Details will be under the `dispute_resolution` object.

electronic_commerce_indicator.description: For electronic commerce transactions, this identifies the level of security used in obtaining the customer's payment credential. For mail or telephone order transactions, identifies the type of mail or telephone order.
x-enum-descriptions: Single transaction of a mail/phone order: Use to indicate that the transaction is a mail/phone order purchase, not a recurring transaction or installment payment. For domestic transactions in the US region, this value may also indicate one bill payment transaction in the card-present or card-absent environments.
Recurring transaction: Payment indicator used to indicate a recurring transaction that originates from an acquirer in the US region.

Installment payment: Payment indicator used to indicate one purchase of goods or services that is billed to the account in multiple charges over a period of time agreed upon by the cardholder and merchant from transactions that originate from an acquirer in the US region.
Unknown classification: other mail order: Use to indicate that the type of mail/telephone order is unknown.
Secure electronic commerce transaction: Use to indicate that the electronic commerce transaction has been authenticated using e.g., 3-D Secure

Non-authenticated security transaction at a 3-D Secure-capable merchant, and merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction where the merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure, but was unable to complete the authentication because the issuer or cardholder does not participate in the 3-D Secure program.

Non-authenticated security transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that uses data encryption for security however , cardholder authentication is not performed using 3-D Secure.
Non-secure transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that has no data protection.

x-enum-descriptions: Single transaction of a mail/phone order: Use to indicate that the transaction is a mail/phone order purchase, not a recurring transaction or installment payment. For domestic transactions in the US region, this value may also indicate one bill payment transaction in the card-present or card-absent environments.
Recurring transaction: Payment indicator used to indicate a recurring transaction that originates from an acquirer in the US region.

Installment payment: Payment indicator used to indicate one purchase of goods or services that is billed to the account in multiple charges over a period of time agreed upon by the cardholder and merchant from transactions that originate from an acquirer in the US region.
Unknown classification: other mail order: Use to indicate that the type of mail/telephone order is unknown.
Secure electronic commerce transaction: Use to indicate that the electronic commerce transaction has been authenticated using e.g., 3-D Secure

Non-authenticated security transaction at a 3-D Secure-capable merchant, and merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction where the merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure, but was unable to complete the authentication because the issuer or cardholder does not participate in the 3-D Secure program.

Non-authenticated security transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that uses data encryption for security however , cardholder authentication is not performed using 3-D Secure.
Non-secure transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that has no data protection.

declined_transaction.title: Declined Transaction
declined_transaction.description: If the Real Time Payments Transfer attempt fails, this will contain the resulting [Declined Transaction](#declined-transactions) object. The Declined Transaction's `source` will be of `category: inbound_real_time_payments_transfer_decline`.

account_id.description: The identifier for the Account the Declined Transaction belongs to.

amount.description: The Declined Transaction amount in the minor unit of its currency. For dollars, for example, this is cents.

currency.description: The [ISO 4217](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217) code for the Declined Transaction's currency. This will match the currency on the Declined Transcation's Account.

created_at.description: The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) date on which the Transaction occured.

description.description: This is the description the vendor provides.

route_id.description: The identifier for the route this Declined Transaction came through. Routes are things like cards and ACH details.

route_type.description: The type of the route this Declined Transaction came through.

source.title: Declined Transaction Source
source.description: This is an object giving more details on the network-level event that caused the Declined Transaction. For example, for a card transaction this lists the merchant's industry and location. Note that for backwards compatibility reasons, additional undocumented keys may appear in this object. These should be treated as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

category.description: The type of decline that took place. We may add additional possible values for this enum over time; your application should be able to handle such additions gracefully.
x-enum-descriptions: The Declined Transaction was created by a ACH Decline object. Details will be under the `ach_decline` object.
The Declined Transaction was created by a Card Decline object. Details will be under the `card_decline` object.
The Declined Transaction was created by a Check Decline object. Details will be under the `check_decline` object.
The Declined Transaction was created by a Inbound Real Time Payments Transfer Decline object. Details will be under the `inbound_real_time_payments_transfer_decline` object.
The Declined Transaction was created by a International ACH Decline object. Details will be under the `international_ach_decline` object.
The Declined Transaction was created by a Deprecated Card Decline object. Details will be under the `card_route_decline` object.
The Declined Transaction was made for an undocumented or deprecated reason.

merchant_country.description: The country the merchant resides in.

network.description: The payment network used to process this card authorization

electronic_commerce_indicator.description: For electronic commerce transactions, this identifies the level of security used in obtaining the customer's payment credential. For mail or telephone order transactions, identifies the type of mail or telephone order.
x-enum-descriptions: Single transaction of a mail/phone order: Use to indicate that the transaction is a mail/phone order purchase, not a recurring transaction or installment payment. For domestic transactions in the US region, this value may also indicate one bill payment transaction in the card-present or card-absent environments.
Recurring transaction: Payment indicator used to indicate a recurring transaction that originates from an acquirer in the US region.

Installment payment: Payment indicator used to indicate one purchase of goods or services that is billed to the account in multiple charges over a period of time agreed upon by the cardholder and merchant from transactions that originate from an acquirer in the US region.
Unknown classification: other mail order: Use to indicate that the type of mail/telephone order is unknown.
Secure electronic commerce transaction: Use to indicate that the electronic commerce transaction has been authenticated using e.g., 3-D Secure

Non-authenticated security transaction at a 3-D Secure-capable merchant, and merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction where the merchant attempted to authenticate the cardholder using 3-D Secure, but was unable to complete the authentication because the issuer or cardholder does not participate in the 3-D Secure program.

Non-authenticated security transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that uses data encryption for security however , cardholder authentication is not performed using 3-D Secure.
Non-secure transaction: Use to identify an electronic commerce transaction that has no data protection.
